The paintings are also heavily decorated with magical symbols, as if they are themselves enchanted.  The hall continues north, west and south.

extras.text: A blue pillar lies to the southwest, decorated with many runes.  Perhaps "decorated" is not the right word - as they are arcane runes symbolizing flight and safety, they are probably functional rather than just for show.
These magical signs are interwoven with chrysoprase, giving them a beauty unrelated to their power.  Some on the east wall are made of silver rather than just engraved in the stone.
A very realistic-looking elf stares at you, as if expecting a greeting.

rooms.name: A Hall of Chrysoprase
rooms.description: The hall narrows to the east and widens to the south, though passage is possible in both directions.  Walls cold to the touch lie to the north and west, tastefully decorated with bright green chrysoprase.  The ceiling is also decorated with a painting, though it arches slightly rather than being flat like much of the rest of the hall.  The air is brisk but not cold.

extras.text: These paintings show a beautiful landscape of forests and mountains with a lost-looking, badly scarred elf with chrysoprase eyes stumbling through the beauty.
Abstract engravings are studded with green chrysoprase gems, though their cold is a good indicator that this is one of the outside walls of the building.

rooms.name: A Hall of Chrysoprase
rooms.description: The hall is warm in this area, though not uncomfortably so.  Arcane symbols dot the walls and ceiling, many inlaid with chrysoprase, some glimmering with arcane power.  The ash crown, the bark totem, and the inscribed pentagram in particular draw the eye.  The hall continues east and west, though walls block passage north and south.

extras.text: A bark totem of the goddess Mielikki is carved into the wall here, near a crown of ashes.  Unusual symbols indeed.
A circle of flowing text surrounds a pentagram here.  The text reads: "The mercenary stood to the left of his friend from Anduin".

rooms.name: A Hall of Chrysoprase
rooms.description: The hall takes a sharp turn here, leading north and west.  The corner to the southeast is richly decorated with chrysoprase and silver, and the ceiling above is tiled with an intricate mosaic.  A light breeze comes from the north, giving the place a bit of fresh air.  The solid green of the chrysoprase looks aesthetically pleasing next to the polished blue stone that makes up the hall, so whoever built this place must have had quite an eye for beauty.

extras.text: Tesserae of many colors, some probably made from precious gemstones, show the story of an injured elf taking refuge in a mountain city that looks suspiciously like Anduin before the Riftwars.

Green and silver form themselves into the shape of a giant dragon flying over the trees.  Silver seems like an unusual color for a dragon, but then maybe the artist didn't have any dragon-shaped pieces of chrysoberyl.

rooms.name: A Hall of Chrysoprase
rooms.description: The hall runs north-south here, somewhat narrower than elsewhere but still quite wide.  The wind blows steadily from the north, chilling the atmosphere. A bright mosaic above you decorates the ceiling, and chrysoprase of varying sizes line the walls.  The western wall is very cold to the touch.  Farther to the north there is a light, as though from the sky, and to the south the hall grows warmer.

extras.text: The mosaic shows a handsome but cruel-looking elf standing outside a jail cell, where a brown-haired man clad in a ruined violet tunic is kept prisoner.
The green chrysoprase is set into the blue stone of the walls very skillfully, and many of the carvings have a Dwarven touch.

rooms.name: A Turn in the Hall
rooms.description: The gemstone-covered hall suddenly turns south and east here, giving a stunning view of the surrounding area off the edge of the floating building to the north.  The wall gently curves to allow a beautiful frame for the natural wonder of being situated very high above the rest of the world.  Keeping in mind, however, that you ARE very high above the world, trying to continue north is likely a very bad idea.  The green chrysoprase is hardly noticeable next to the eye-catching power of the world from above, but the gems still highlight carvings on the walls and the mosaic above you.

extras.text: To the north lies the world.  Water gleams, clouds shadow, and trees grow wherever the eyes turn.  It is a veritable living tapestry, though you are too high up to see the forms of living creatures.  It is quite a mesmerizing view.

Brilliant tiles show the image of a dirty-looking girl in a barbarian village.  Though she is clad only in animal skins, she is grinning brightly and her hair has the glint of silver.  Her eyes are tiny chrysoprase stones, seeming very green.  Barely noticeable on her forehead is the symbol of two concentric circles.

rooms.name: A Turn in the Hallway
rooms.description: A blast of cold wind from the north sends a shiver down the spine.  In that direction, you can see the outside of the floating fortress, and - no surprise - it is extremely high off the ground.  Far to the north, there is a glimmer of a large body of water, and closer to you the ground is dappled with trees, the tops of peaks, and more.  The clouds make a whole landscape of their own: some wispy and some puffy, and some larger than any earthly mountain.  However, going north would not be wise, as it would drop you for a very long way before you would reach the ground.  The ceiling is covered with a beautiful mosaic, and the hall itself turns here, leading west and south.

extras.text: The slight sparkle of a body of water far to the north is probably the Blue Fog Sea.  However, from here is color is unclear.

The clouds below you are definately magical in nature, behaving nothing at all like normal clouds.  The normal clouds, on the other hand, are visible for many miles and have their own beauty.  What god makes them?  What god sweeps them into such formations, each so different and ever-changing that one can stare at it and see anything?

The ceiling mosaic is covered with a thin layer of ice due to the constant elemental exposure, but its subject remains clear.  A young, silver-haired woman looks in astonishment at a priestess and an aging druid in a rustic forest village.  The young woman is dressed plainly, like the others in the village, but the two heroes greeting her are richly attired.  A few of their ornaments are studded with smoky quartz to add emphasis to their wealth.

rooms.name: A Hall of Smoky Quartz
rooms.description: The smoky quartz crystals studding the room make the light jump out from every crevice and carving.  The ceiling is a series of magical symbols, such as an angelic being, a triangle, and an inscribed pentagram, with occasional runes being made of the same smoky quartz that is present everywhere else.  The hall is narrower here than is it elsewhere, with walls to the east and west.  The eastern wall is very cold to the touch, probably because it borders directly on the atmosphere.  Progress is possible both north and south.

extras.text: The pentagram is inscribed not with a line, but with flowing text which reads: "The gnome stood in the middle, surrounded by the others".

Some seem merely decorative while others shimmer with contained power. Though it is unusual to use smoky quartz in runic writing, the effect is pleasing to the eye.  The other symbols are etched into the stone.

rooms.name: A Hall of Smoky Quartz
rooms.description: This hallway is encrusted with smoky quartz, softly drawing attention to the designs which cover walls and ceiling.  Above you is a painting done in greens and silver.  A wall lies to your west, and the hall is wide to the east and south.  It narrows to the north, from which a chilly breeze flows.  A pillar lies to the southeast, supporting the hallway.

extras.text: This painting shows the figure of a woman with silver hair diligently studying texts written in various scripts.  Her eyes are represented by tiny studs of smoky quartz.
A large pillar of blue stone stands here inscribed with the magical runes for fight and safety.  It is probably necessary for support of the wide hall.

rooms.name: A Hall of Smoky Quartz
rooms.description: You are on the northern end of a wide hallway of blue stone and smoky quartz.  Pillars stand to the southeast and southwest, and figures of heroes decorate the northern wall and the ceiling.  The air is brisk but not cold, circulating gently.  The wide hall continues to the east, south, and west.

extras.text: The paintings in this room depict two heroes, a silver-haired woman wearing the garb of a ranger and a dark-haired man in a druid's robe.  They are holding hands and smiling.
Large blue pillars stand to the southeast and southwest, made of the same stone that the rest of the structure uses.  Both are inscribed with magical runes of flight and safety.

rooms.name: A Hall of Smoky Quartz
rooms.description: You are in the northeastern corner of a wide hallway of blue stone studded with smoky quartz.  Shapes and lines abound in this end of the hall, with a bit of the dark quartz accenting a rectangle, a spiral, a clover, an inscribed pentagram, and more.  A pillar supports the hallway to the southwest, and the hallway itself continues both south and west.

extras.text: If the shapes have a pattern, it is not readily obvious.  The quartz seems to be scattered at random, aesthetically pleasing intervals.
The circle in which this pentagram is not a line, but small, flowing script. It reads, "The rogue learned to like indigo in his hometown of Anduin".
A large pillar of blue stone stands to the southwest, supporting the hall. It is inscribed with the magical runes for safety and flight.

rooms.name: A Hall of Aventurine
rooms.description: This is the northern end of the wide, aventurine-covered hall.  Pillars rise to the southeast and southwest, supporting the ceiling.  The ceiling itself is covered with a painting, accented by careful placement of the green and blue gemstone crystals.  The hall continues in all directions except north, where a wall blocks passage.

extras.text: Solid blue pillars rise to the southeast and southwest, providing the structural integrity necessary to support a hall of these proportions.  They are also inscribed with magical runes for safety and flight.

The ceiling is painted with a beautiful portrait of a sad child, His pointed ears show that he is either elven or half-elven, and, while other children play together in the background, he stands alone.

rooms.name: A Hall of Aventurine
rooms.description: This is the northeast corner of the large hall.  It is tastefully decorated with different symbols, including a perfect triangle, a burning heart, and an inscribed pentagram.  Aventurine and a clear crystal both accentuate the symbols and reflect light pleasantly.  A pillar stands to the southwest, and the hall continues both south and west.

East.description: Clear crystals form a large rectangular shape in this direction.

extras.text: A giant pillar of blue stone stands to the south, bearing the weight of the ceiling.  Inscribed on it are arcane runes of flight and safety.

These symbols, some accented by gemstones, shimmer slightly in the light. The burning heart represents passion and the oak tree protection, though whether they are functional or merely decorative is unknown.
It is a pentagram inscribed in a circle, though upon second glance the circle is not a solid line.  Rather, it is a flowing script, which reads: "He who fought orcs was always clad in magenta".

rooms.name: A Crystal Chamber
rooms.description: Clear crystals scatter the light and refract it into infinite colors, nearly overwhelming the eyes.  Some crystals are carved or formed into fantastic shapes, and many of them look quite sharp.  No trace of the cold is present in these chambers, but neither are they unpleasantly warm.  The crystal chamber continues east and north.

West.description: Looking closely, it appears the crystals are arranged in the shape of a door here.

extras.text: Rather than simply being spires, some of the crystals that make up the chamber are shaped like jagged bolts of lightning, talons of a monstrous bird, air elementals and clouds.

rooms.name: A Crystal Chamber
rooms.description: This is the southeast corner of a room decorated in clear crystals.  It is difficult to tell exactly what kind of crystals they are, since the spires and facets come in many shapes.  All of it seems adept at catching light and then nearly blinding whoever turned the light in that direction.  The chamber continues north and west.

extras.text: Quartz crystals usually have six-pointed spires, and diamonds occur naturally in cubes or octahedrons, but these crystals come in all shapes. They were probably formed artificially.

rooms.name: A Crystal Chamber
rooms.description: This is the northeast corner of the crystal chamber, decorated marvelously with many kinds of carvings and natural-looking spires.  Sometimes the crystals seem to form patterns; sometimes they seem completely random.  The smallest light is refracted thousands of times into tiny rainbows, making the otherwise white room into one that dances with color.  The chamber continues to the west and south.

extras.text: If you focus your eyes one way, you can see a giant bird, but look again and the image is lost.  Or maybe it wasn't a bird, but a beast?  Looking too hard could give one a headache.

rooms.name: A Crystal Chamber
rooms.description: Gleaming surfaces and sharp corners assult the senses, each crystal unique. A smoothly polished stairway of blue stone leads to an upper level here, giving the entire room a blue cast as crystals reflect the color over and over.  The chamber itself continues east and south.

extras.text: Very solid-looking, the stairway is made of the same blue stone that the rest of the castle seems to be constructed of.  Tiny number runes are on each stair, "1" at the bottom, "2" next, and so on.  Apparently there are 43 stairs total.

rooms.name: A Hall of Malachite
rooms.description: This hall is comparatively small, next to the ones on the lower level. Walls enclose you on three sides, decorated sparingly with the precious gem malachite.  The stripes of the green stone draw the eye, unlike many other gems which are solid in color.  A modest painting decorates the ceiling, and the hall opens up to the east.

extras.text: The painting on the ceiling shows a happy, silver-haired woman holding hands with a druid and being chased by two children.  The kids look to be around seven or ten years old, one with silver hair and one with golden hair.

rooms.name: A Hall of Malachite
rooms.description: A hall with high, arched ceilings opens up in all directions here.  Striped green malachite complements the blue stone walls beautifully, decorating everything richly without being too ornate.  It is colder here than in the halls below, and the air is thinner.  Air circulates freely, adding a bit of wind chill.  The painting on the ceiling colors the room brightly.

extras.text: Malachite is a striped green stone that is usually considered too soft to work with, but here it has been added to the ceiling painting to accent parts of the clothing, plants, and other green objects.

The painting shows an angry-looking druid yelling at a hooded figure who holds a tiny, purple-haired baby.  A silver-haired woman clad in green looks exhausted and sad, laying in a bed - she probably just gave birth.

rooms.name: A Malachite Alcove
rooms.description: Walls covered in malachite and magical symbols surround you on three sides, with only the north being open to passage.  Many of the symbols glow with power, including an oak tree, an inscribed pentagram, and a small flame.  It is a little cold here, but not cold enough to threaten frostbite.

extras.text: Here in the corner is a pentagram inscribed in a circle of flowing text. The text reads: "The one who hailed from Nordus stood to the left of the one clad in violet".

The oak tree, a potent symbol of nature, is skillfully embedded with malachite stones as leaves, making it look vibrant.  The flame is small but it is beautiful, calling to mind the warmth and life-giving properties of fire rather than the destructive, harmful ways it has often been used.

rooms.name: The Eastern Overlook
rooms.description: Somehow, though you must realistically be directly above the lower hall, there is nothing but clouds and air below you - and the ground, far far away. A narrow ledge is all that separates you from a long drop.  However, the view is fantastic, from cloudscapes a landbound creature could only dream of to the world below like a mapmaker spends a lifetime making.  The walls of the floating castle protect you from the worst of the elements, but it is still quite cold.  Under a thin layer of ice, the ceiling sports a painting accented by green malachite stones.  The main hall is back to the west, and a nasty drop lies to the east.

extras.text: Many kinds of clouds are visible in the sky, some wispy and higher up and some puffy, about on a level with you.  There are also some clouds that form a wall you can't see through down closer to the ground, making it impossible to make out some of the land's features in some areas.  Other places are clear, though, and allow blurry shapes to be seen.  Details are not visible from this height.

A thin layer of ice covers this beautiful painting, which depicts a druid and a silver-haired woman in ranger's garb sailing on a boat towards a large, green landmass.  The ocean is a stunning blue, but there seems to be no other crew on the ship they are in, though it is quite large.

rooms.name: A Hall of Malachite
rooms.description: The hall, richly decorated with green malachite stones, turns west and south here.  South leads back to more green malachite, but west leads to a gently glowing moonstone-studded hall.  The ceiling is decorated with complex carvings interspersed with malachite for aesthetic effect.  It is rather cold, owing to a slight breeze that circulates around, though this keeps the air very fresh. Walls block passage to the north and east.

extras.text: The walls to the north and east are very cold to the touch.  They probably open directly on to the outer atmosphere...  But they seem quite thick enough to keep out the worst of the cold.

The blue stone which makes up the ceiling is carved into a bas-releif picture of a ranger and a druid making a pact with a variety of forest spirits. The ranger is clad in heavy furs, though the forest looks to be temperate. The druid has a new moon symbol on his forehead.

rooms.name: A Hall of Moonstone
rooms.description: Moonstones give this room a gentle glow, their pale luster catching the smallest bit of light and making it into a ghostly, ephemeral glow.  Wind blows in strongly from the north, and looking in that direction reveals a patch of open sky farther off.  The ceiling is exquisitely carved with bas-relief figures accented by gems.  The hall continues north, east, and west.

extras.text: The carvings here show a maliciousl demon laughing cruelly at an injured druid, while a ranger looks on in horror.  Moonstones speckle the picture, especially around the ranger and the druid.

Moonstone is a soft-looking, pale greyish stone with tiny flecks of gold or silver in it, though sometimes it is clear..  It is called "moonstone" because the color is similar to that of a white or silver moon.

rooms.name: The Northern Overlook
rooms.description: The moonstones that decorate this overlook are muted by the vast landscape stretching out to the north.  Though many clouds are visible, some below you, they do not wholly block the view of the lands below.  Only large features like the mountains are distinguishable due to the great height, and the clouds themselves form a landscape of their own that few nonflying creatures would ever imagine.  Continuing north, however beautiful it looks, would surely result in a painful drop, so the southern retreat would be much more sensible. The walls are covered in faint signs, including an inscribed pentagram.

extras.text: There is a pentagram inscribed in a circle, nearly covered in ice, on the western wall.  However, the circle is not a solid line, but rather a line of flowing text which reads: "He who liked indigo was fond of fighting bugs".

Sharp and fluffy, thin and thick, clouds of every descriptor are visible. The higher ones are thinner and sharper-looking, blowing about swiftly in the heavy winds.  Down lie some softer-looking clouds and, below them, the ground. It looks like a long drop.

rooms.name: A Hall of Moonstone
rooms.description: The gentle radiance of pale moonstones give this room a cool, yet comforting, feel.  The walls and ceiling are covered with engraved figures and scenes accented by the gems - surely the work of a master artisan.  Cold winds circulate, making the hall slightly uncomfortable.  Though walls lie to the north and west, passage is possible both south and east.

extras.text: The carvings in this part of the hall show a beautiful woman in ranger's garb pleading with some stubborn-looking forest spirits while a druid lies badly injured nearby.  The woman's hair is silvery, and all the eyes in the picture are replaced with moonstones.

rooms.name: A Hall of Moonstone
rooms.description: The hall embedded with moonstones ends here at a door to the south but continues north and west.  Winds blow in strongly from the west, though north seems calmer.  The door in the southern wall has an artistic representation of the sun - rather odd for a hall full of in moonstones.  The ceiling is decorated with bas-relief carvings, like the rest of this hall.

South.description: The door is inset with moonstones in the shape of the rising sun.  Someone must have had a strange sense of humor.

extras.text: The carvings here are masterful but sad.  The subject of the ornamentation is a woman descending into madness over the death of her beloved.  The woman is beautiful in her sorrow, but it is a rather chilling scene.
The door is inset with moonstones in the shape of the rising sun.  Someone must have had a strange sense of humor.

rooms.name: The Western Overlook
rooms.description: The hall opens up here, giving a wide view of the surrounding lands.  Far off to the west is the glint of an ocean, though closer lie a forest and a mountain range.  Here and there lie massive clouds, obscuring some features of the lands below.  Most are obscured by the great height, though.  The hall itself, covered in moonstones and carvings on the ceiling, continues back to the east.  A nasty drop lies to the west.

extras.text: The carvings on the ceiling are precise and eye-pleasing, though their subject is somewhat grim.  They show a woman in ranger's garb howling in grief near a grave marker while the forest decays around her.  It is as though a shadow is eminating from her, turning the once-beautiful forest into a swampy wasteland.  Her forehead shows a symbol of two concentric circles in gold, edged in black.

rooms.name: A Hall of Celestite
rooms.description: The dark blue stone in this hall is embedded with crystals of the rare and precious gem celestite, giving the room a dappled, sparkling look.  An image of the rising sun done in red gold on the door to the north makes the room reminiscent of a winter's morning - because it is certainly cold.  Detailed carvings decorate the ceiling, and a wide stairway leads up into blue-tinged darkness.  The hall also continues to the east.

North.description: Inlaid with rare, expensive red gold is the image of the rising sun on the door to the north.

extras.text: Carefully carved bas-relief style figures on the ceiling show a bereaved woman in a dark swamp looking pleadingly at the image of a goddess.  The goddess is marked with an ancient symbol for destiny and endings, and a wave of her hand in the next panel shows the woman dead and peaceful expressions on both faces.  Celestite accents both panels beautifully.

Inlaid with rare, expensive red gold is the image of the rising sun on the door to the north.  It shimmers gorgeously in even the faintest light, standing out all the more because it is surrounded by the dark blue stone of the walls and the pale blue celestite crystals.

rooms.name: A Hall of Celestite
rooms.description: The hall curves sharply south and west here, with a cold wind blowing in from the south.  Set in the walls are many beautiful celestite crystals, their pale blue matching the morning sky.  A massive emblem of two dragons locked in battle dominates the ceiling, drawing the eye upwards.  Between the precious metals used to decorate it and the sheer quantity of gemstones decorating the walls, this floating tower must have cost a fortune to decorate.

extras.text: Celestite is a pale blue stone, very rare in most parts of the world.  Its crystals form four-pointed shapes that catch the light and sparkle easily, multiplying any light in the hall into a brilliant glimmer.

On the ceiling are two dragons locked in battle, the carving so realistic that the artist must have studied at least one live dragon.  On the southern end is a massive wyrm done in silver with sapphire eyes and diamond talons and fangs.  Snarling at it viciously from the northern end of the room is a dragon inlaid with a green metal with emeralds for eyes and ruby blood dripping from its diamond fangs and talons.  The reason for their battle cannot be concluded from the picture, but it surely shook the world if it actually happened.

rooms.name: The Southern Overlook
rooms.description: Pale blue celestite on dark blue stone gives the overlook an icy feel which is compounded by the chill southern wind.  Symbols of arcane power line the walls, including alchemists' circles, an inscribed pentagram, and a series of runes.  South lies a stunning view of the lands below, full of forests and lakes and even a smudge that might be a city.  Mountainous clouds dominate the view.  Continuing south would be unwise, as the hall opens onto empty air. The celestite hall continues north.

extras.text: There is a pentagram inscribed in a circle, barely noticeable against the eastern wall.  The circle is a line of text which reads: "The gnome was often clad in lavendar".
The symbols are scattered here, many glowing with a cool light.  The runes are arcane runes of light and protection, and the alchemical circles seem to be decorative rather than functional.

rooms.name: In the Clouds
rooms.description: More wind, more clouds and more cold are all that is here.  The air is thin, but the heavy winds ensure that there is a lot of it.  White fills your vision to all directions, and down is the only way to go.  Were the winds not so strong it would be possible to go up, but even magical flight cannot stand against the obviously magical downdraft.

rooms.name: In the Sapphire Tower
rooms.description: You are in a tower spire on top of the floating building.  The walls here are not covered with the semiprecious stones of the lower levels, but with valuable sapphires.  Varying in size from mere pricks of blue to ones as big as a robin's egg, they bring to mind a vast amount of wealth.  The walls to the west and south seem to suck away heat, likely because they are the outer walls of the tower.  There is also a wall to the east, though the north remains open. You could also retreat back down.

rooms.name: In the Sapphire Tower
rooms.description: The brilliant gleam of sapphires dominates this room, giving everything an azure tint.  A deep, almost subaural thrumming is testament to the strength of the winds outside the tower, but it seems stable enough inside.  Richly decorated walls rise to the north and west, keeping out the cold.  The rest of the tower is accessible to the east or south, with a strangely violent feeling persisting to the east.

rooms.name: In the Sapphire Tower
rooms.description: Static electricity is strong in this room, giving the sapphires on the walls a unique radiance.  It is very cold here, as you must be near the top of the tower by now.  A blue door stands to the south, and the tower continues to the west as well.  This room is exceptionally windy for being completely enclosed, and it does not feel nearly as safe as some of the other rooms in this tower. The room's decorations are, though, if possible even more beautiful than those in the rooms below.

South.description: A door encrusted with sapphires blocks passage south.

extras.text: The sapphires are either carved with exquisite skill or shaped by magic, because fist-sized chunks of the blue gem are shaped like many dangerous and beautiful creatures.  Here is a dragon, there is a seraph, over there is a couatl...

rooms.name: A Spiral Staircase in the Sapphire Tower
rooms.description: This room is very quiet and peaceful after the atmospheric disturbances present in other parts of the tower.  Sapphires lining the walls draw the eyes to a large spiral staircase leading up, beyond which you can see the sky - it must lead to the top of the tower.  A door leads north, going back into the tower.

rooms.name: Dargentan's Lair
rooms.description: The elements suddenly assault the top of the structure, which is very noisy compared to the inner sanctum below.  Breathtaking views of the tops of clouds and mountains appear on all sides, though it would be dangerously easy to slide off the edges as the platform-like area has no ledges.  A shallow indent in the very center of the floor has been scraped into the solid stone by a large silver dragon.  Shed scales litter the ground, but there is no sign of the mound of treasure one usually expects a dragon to hoard.  Upon reflection however, the dragon IS sleeping on top of a gem-encrusted castle.  Perhaps his treasure is simply to be found in a different form than usual.

rooms.name: In the Clouds
rooms.description: Oops.  It looks like you've fallen off an unsafe edge.  Now the ground is far below you - very far below you.  The winds from above beat down so strongly that the only way to go is down.  Hopefully the ground below is soft, because otherwise the drop is really going to hurt.

rooms.name: In the Clouds
rooms.description: Winds and clouds surround you on all sides, blocking any view of the outside world.  It is extremely cold, and the winds are so strong that the only way to go is down.  And a long way down it is.  If there isn't something soft down there, things could get messy.

rooms.name: In the Clouds
rooms.description: Down, down, down blow the winds around you.  Yet the elements seem magically controlled here, probably by the master of the castle which the clouds part to reveal here.  It is a magnificent vision of brilliant blues and whites, giving an impression of an inverted icicle.  But it is quite unreachable from here, as the winds only permit travel downward.

rooms.name: In the Clouds
rooms.description: The clouds swirl around once again, blocking all view of the surroundings. All directions are full of white, the misty clouds closing in on you.  Though the winds are strong, they beat down so hard that down is the only direction travel is possible.

rooms.name: In the Clouds
rooms.description: The winds are very strong here, too strong to allow upward travel.  Clouds alternately cover and reveal a large, dark mass far above which blocks the sunlight, making a chilly environment even colder.  Hopefully there is something below to catch you should you fall, because you are very high up indeed.

rooms.name: In the Clouds
rooms.description: The cloudy platform is visible far below, and there is nothing but air all around, broken only by the occasional bird.  The wind is much stronger here, making upward travel very difficult but still possible.  It looks like quite a drop from here, but luckily the cloudy platform is there to catch you should you fall.

rooms.name: In the Clouds
rooms.description: The platform of solid cloud is a ways below you here, and empty air surrounds you in the cardinal directions.  There is a dark mass high above you, blocking the sunlight.  The wind beats down steadily from above, perhaps coming from the dark mass.  The surrounding countryside is visible, as you are now much higher above the treetops.  Progress up or down is unimpeded, though down is a bit easier.
